en.value: Where did you go to school?
Talking about our education - Questions and negative sentences in the past simple
Where did you go to school? Did you go to university? What did you study? Now we’re going to learn how to answer all of these questions and more. Let’s go!
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
I went to school in Berlin.
He's going to university in Holland.

It’s also very common to use “to be at school / university”, when we want to talk about the period of time we spent somewhere. In some contexts it means the same as “to go to school / university”. Have a look below to see a few examples.
I went to university when I was 19. / I was at university when I was 19.
You went to school together. / You were at school together.
She went to school in Hamburg. / She was at school in Hamburg.
I was at school with your brother!
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
What is Ricco going to do after he finishes school?
He is going to the library.
You can also "learn about something" or you can "learn (how) to do something".
to learn about something: I learned a lot about marketing at my last job.
to learn (how) to do something: I'm learning how to play the guitar.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
He failed one of his final exams.
I passed my driving test in 2018.
He passed Physics and failed Chemistry.
He passed both Physics and Maths.
He failed both Physics and Chemistry.
Have another look at all the words we've learned:
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Two students are talking about their exams.
How are your exams going, Ashley?
I’m almost done! I [k]sat[/k] English and Maths last week, so now I just have Biology and Chemistry.
Cool! Did you [k]pass[/k] English and Maths?
I passed Maths. I don’t know about English yet. I think I [k]failed[/k]…
Ah ok. What are your plans after you [k]finish[/k] school?
I think I am [k]going to university[/k] in Boston.
I want to study Natural Science, so I can [k]learn[/k] about molecular biology.
Complete the sentence "Ashley ... Biology and Chemistry."
Select the words in the correct order.
Select the word with the opposite meaning to “passed”.
He took geography, but he [h]failed[/h] it.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
I [k]l[/k][k]e[/k][k]a[/k][k]r[/k][k]n[/k][k]e[/k][k]d[/k] how to code in Java.
She [k]passed[/k] all her tests last month.
Fill in the gap using the image.
Where did you go to school or university? What did you study?
I went to university in Bristol. I studied Oceanography. I learned a lot about ...

So far we've learned how to form basic sentences in the past simple using regular and irregular verbs. Now, let's take a look at forming negative sentences and questions in the past simple. Have a look at the examples below and see if you can work out what they mean.
He did not study French at university.
He did not study French at university.
We did not go to school together.
This sentence is in the past simple.
To form negative sentences in the past simple we need the words "did" and "not". We use this structure: person / thing + "did" + "not" + verb (base form).
Remember: We do not use the past simple form of the main verb in the sentence. We keep the base form.
I did not take chemistry at school.
He did not learn how to swim.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
We use shortened forms in the past simple, too. "Did not" often becomes "didn't", especially in spoken language.
My children [k]d[/k][k]i[/k][k]d[/k][k]n[/k][k]'[/k][k]t[/k] go to the same school.
We need the word "did" when forming questions in the past simple, too. The structure we use is as follows: "did" + person + verb (base form).
Did they learn to swim when they were children?
Select the negative sentence in the past simple.
Chad didn't pass his driving test first time.
Chad passed his driving test first time.
Chad doesn't pass his driving test first time.
We can also add a wh-question word / phrase at the beginning of the sentence to ask different kinds of questions. Have a look at the examples below.
Where did you learn how to speak French?
What subject did she study at university?
[k]Did[/k] you [k]learn[/k] to drive when you were 16?
We [k]didn't meet|did not meet[/k] at university.
I [k]didn't pass|did not pass[/k] my Maths exam.
Complete the question in the past simple below with "you" and the verb "to meet".
I didn't [k]get[/k] a car until I was 21.
Rewrite this sentence to make it negative.
You called your mum last night.
[k]You didn't call your mum|You did not call your mum[/k] last night.
Rewrite this sentence as a question with the word "when".
